chapterTitle: Return, Risk, and The Security Market Line

columns.text: In this exercise, we are asked to assess the security market line.

The **security market line** is a line that shows the correlation between the expected return and volatility of a security. In other terms, this is the capital asset pricing model (CAPM), which plots varying degrees of risk associated with different investments across the market's projected to return at any particular moment.

Let's first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Expected return  |11.8%|
|Beta  | 1.10 | 
|Risk-free rate  |3.3%|

First, let us calculate different combinations of expected returns and betas for portfolios of Asset W and a risk-free asset. We will use the formula below to determine the expected returns. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio expected return}&={\text{(PP $\times$ ER) + [(1 -  PP) $\times$ RFR]}}
\end{aligned}$$


Where:

PP = Percentage of portfolio

ER= Expected return 

RFR = Risk-free rate

Let us first determine the portfolio expected return of Asset W, considering a 25 percentage of the portfolio. This is computed using the formula from step 4. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio expected return}&={\text{(25\% $\times$ 11.8\%) + [(1 -  25\%) $\times$ 3.3\%]}}\\
&={\text{2.95\% +2.48\%}}\\
&={\textbf{5.43\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 25 percentage of the portfolio is 5.43%.**

Next, let us determine the portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 50 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio expected return}&={\text{(50\% $\times$ 11.8\%) + [(1 -  50\%) $\times$ 3.3\%]}}\\
&={\text{5.9\% + 1.65\%}}\\
&={\textbf{7.55\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 50 percentage of the portfolio is 7.55%.**

Then, let us determine the portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 75 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio expected return}&={\text{(75\% $\times$ 11.8\%) + [(1 -  75\%) $\times$ 3.3\%]}}\\
&={\text{8.85\% + 0.83\%}}\\
&={\textbf{9.68\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 75 percentage of the portfolio is 9.68%.**

Now, let us determine the portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 100 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio expected return}&={\text{(100\% $\times$ 11.8\%) + [(1 -  100\%) $\times$ 3.3\%]}}\\
&={\text{11.8\% + 0}}\\
&={\textbf{11.8\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 100 percentage of the portfolio is 11.8%.**

Next, let us determine the portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 125 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio expected return}&={\text{(125\% $\times$ 11.8\%) + [(1 -  125\%) $\times$ 3.3\%]}}\\
&={\text{14.75\% - 0.83\%}}\\
&={\textbf{13.92\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 125 percentage of the portfolio is 13.92%.**

Then, let us determine the portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 150 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio expected return}&={\text{(150\% $\times$ 11.8\%) + [(1 -  150\%) $\times$ 3.3\%]}}\\
&={\text{17.70\% - 1.65\%}}\\
&={\textbf{16.05\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio expected return of Asset W considering a 150 percentage of the portfolio is 16.05%.**

Now that we have determined the expected returns, we will then compute for the beta of each portfolio. This is computed as follows:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio beta}&={\text{Percentage of Portfolio $\times$ Security beta}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Let us first determine the portfolio beta of Asset W, considering 25 percentage of the portfolio. This is computed using the formula from step 11. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio beta}&={\text{25\% $\times$ 1.10}}\\
&={\textbf{0.275}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 25 percentage of the portfolio is 0.275.**

Next, let us determine the portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 50 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio beta}&={\text{50\% $\times$ 1.10}}\\
&={\textbf{0.55}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 50 percentage of the portfolio is 0.55.**

Then, let us determine the portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 75 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio beta}&={\text{75\% $\times$ 1.10}}\\
&={\textbf{0.825}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 75 percentage of the portfolio is 0.825.**

Now, let us determine the portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 100 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio beta}&={\text{100\% $\times$ 1.10}}\\
&={\textbf{1.10}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 100 percentage of the portfolio is 1.10.**

Next, let us determine the portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 125 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio beta}&={\text{125\% $\times$ 1.10}}\\
&={\textbf{1.375}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 125 percentage of the portfolio is 1.375.**

Then, let us determine the portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 150 percentage of portfolio. This is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Portfolio beta}&={\text{150\% $\times$ 1.10}}\\
&={\textbf{1.65}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

**The portfolio beta of Asset W considering a 150 percentage of the portfolio is 1.65.**

Now, let compute the slope of the line for Asset W. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Slope}&=\dfrac{\text{Expected return - Risk-free rate }}{\text{Beta}}\\
&=\dfrac{\text{11.8\% - 3.3\% }}{\text{1.10}}\\
&={\textbf{0.0773 or 7.73\%}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

**The slope of Asset W is 7.73%.**

Then, let us complete the table provided in this item. The table with its portfolio expected return and portfolio beta is as follows: 


| Percentage of Portfolio in Asset W| Portfolio Expected Return | Portfolio Beta| 
|--|:--:|:--:| 
|$\hspace{5pt}$ 0% | 3.30%| 0| 
|$\hspace{5pt}$ 25% |5.43% | 0.275| 
|$\hspace{5pt}$ 50% |7.55% | 0.550| 
|$\hspace{5pt}$ 75% | 9.68%| 0.825| 
|$\hspace{5pt}$ 100% |11.80% | 1.10| 
|$\hspace{5pt}$ 125% | 13.92%| 1.375| 
|$\hspace{5pt}$ 150% | 16.05%| 1.65|

Now, let's plot the portfolio expected returns and portfolio betas combinations. The security market line (SML) is shown as follows: 

!['slader'](https://slader-solution-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/2c3851f9-9541-46c7-87e4-f72fe1e53a94-1641907228011295.jpeg)
**To conclude, we obtain a straight line when we plot the combinations of portfolio expected returns and portfolio betas.**
